text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
hello I'm Kuma a technical account
manager here at the AWS office in Cape
Town today I'm going to show you how you
can improve the transfer of performance
using the sync command for Amazon simple
storage service let's get
started to copy a large amount of data
you can run multiple instances of the
AWS command line interface or c
from different terminals to perform
separate sync operations in Amazon S3 in
parallel for example you might want to
perform parallel sync operations for
different prefixes or you might want to
use separate exclude and include
filters let's perform multiple sync
operations for different prefixes start
by opening two instances of the AWS CLI
run the AWS S3 sync command for the
first S3 prefix
run the AWS S3 sync command for the
second S3 prefix the first AWS S3 sync
command syncs the contents of folder one
from the source bucket to the
destination bucket and the second
command sinks the condens of folder two
from The Source bucket to the
destination
bucket next let's look at how you can
perform parallel sync operations for
separate exclude and include
filters start by opening two instances
of the AWS
CLI run the AWS S3 sync command for the
first
filter run the AWS F3 sync command for
the second
filter the First Command excludes all
files and includes only files with the
extension.
EXE the second command excludes all
files and includes only files with the
MP4 extension if you want to run more
than 10 concurrent parallel sync
transfers you must update the
configuration value for Max concurrent
requests as follows open the AWS CLI run
the following command to update the
configuration for the default profile to
20 Max concurrent
requests if you want to update the
configuration for a profile other than
default use the following command
note that running more threads on a
computer will consume more resources be
sure that your computer has enough
resources to handle the maximum number
of concurrent requests that you want to
run too many concurrent requests can
overwhelm a system which can result in
slow response time or even timeouts you
can avoid timeouts by setting the-- CLI
read timeout value or the-- CLI connect
timeout value to zero if you want to use
a sync operation in an Amazon elastic
compute Cloud instance or or ec2
instance consider the
following review the instance type that
you're using larger instance types can
provide better results because they have
high bandwidth and Amazon EBS store
optimized networks if the ec2 instances
in a different AWS region than the
bucket then use an instance in the same
region to reduce latency reduce the
geographical distance between the
instance and your Amazon S3 bucket if
the instance is in the same region in a
source bucket then set up an Amazon
virtual private cloud or VPC endpoint
for Amazon S3 VPC endpoints can help
improve overall performance also be sure
that your bucket doesn't have a lot of
delete markers as this affects list
performance because the syn command runs
list API calls in the back end a bucket
with a lot of delete markers will affect
the performance of the syn command as
well so now you know how to copy a large
amount of data by running multiple
instances of the a W CLI from different
terminals to perform separate syn
operations in parallel using either
different prefixes or separate exclude
and include filters thanks for watching
and happy cloud computing from all of us
here at AWS
[Applause]
[Music]
[Music]
